# Draft:John Edward Jones (Victim of Nutty Putty Cave incident)

----
John Edward Jones (21 January, 1983 â€“ November 24, 2009) was a 26-year-old American medical student who tragically died in a caving accident at Nutty Putty Cave, located in Utah County, Utah, United States. His death highlighted the inherent dangers of caving and led to increased awareness about cave safety.
Early Life and Education
Born in Salt Lake City, Utah, John Edward Jones was the youngest of five children in a devout family of The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints. Raised in a close-knit family, he developed a passion for the outdoors and caving from an early age. He attended the University of Virginia School of Medicine, where he was pursuing a career in pediatric cardiology. At the time of his death, he was married to Emily, with whom he had a daughter, Lizzie, and a second child due in June 2010.
Family
Jones was married to Emily, and they had a young daughter, Lizzie (1 year old) , at the time of the incident. Emily was pregnant with their second child. He was close to his siblings, one of whom accompanied him during the Nutty Putty Cave exploration. His death had a profound impact on his family, who later shared his story to raise awareness about cave safety and to honor his memory.
Nutty Putty Cave Incident
On November 24, 2009, Jones visited Nutty Putty Cave with his brother Josh and a group of friends. While attempting to locate a narrow passage known as the "Birth Canal", he got into a different unmapped section of the cave that was called "Ed's Push". He got wedged upside down in a hole present at the unmapped section. Despite extensive rescue efforts, including attempts to pull him out using a pulley system, Jones remained trapped. After over 24 hours, rescuers were unable to free him, and he tragically passed away in the cave. The rescuers realized that the pulley system wouldn't work and they would need to break John's legs to rescue him, but his legs had gone cold due to all of the blood in his body being concentrated at his shoulders. Paramedics were called and confirmed John's death on November 24th, 2009. The body had become irrecoverable and left inside the wedge where he had initially gotten stuck.
Aftermath
Following the incident, Nutty Putty Cave was permanently closed to the public. The cave's closure was a response to the dangers highlighted by Jones's death and aimed to prevent similar accidents in the future. The entrance to the cave was sealed with concrete, and a plaque was placed at the site to honor his memory.
Legacy
Jones's death brought attention to the risks associated with Caving and the importance of safety measures. His story has been featured in various media outlets, and the incident has been discussed in the context of cave safety and rescue operations. In 2016, the film The Last Descent was released, dramatizing the events surrounding his death and subsequent rescue efforts.
